title: 110_hr3224
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dam Rehabilitation and Repair Act of 2007" and focuses on the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include definitions for "deficient dam" and "rehabilitation." The Act focuses on the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a program for the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. SEC. 8A. Rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. The Director will establish a program within FEMA to provide grant assistance to States for rehabilitating publicly-owned deficient dams. States can apply for grants by submitting an application to the Director, who may award grants based on regulations. States must meet standards set by the Director when applying for grants. The Director will require States applying for grants to comply with specific standards and develop a risk-based priority system for identifying deficient dams. Funds allocated for grants will be divided equally among applying States. The grants under this section are distributed to States based on the number of deficient dams posing a danger to human health within each State. The Federal share of rehabilitation costs for a deficient dam cannot exceed 65 percent. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 for this section. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2008 to 2012 are as follows: $10,000,000 for 2008, $15,000,000 for 2009, $25,000,000 for 2010, $50,000,000 for 2011, and $100,000,000 for 2012. Additionally, $400,000 is allocated for FEMA staff employment for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010. The funds allocated in this section are available until expended. The Director of FEMA must issue a proposed rule within 90 days and a final rule within 120 days after the enactment of the Act regarding amendments to the National Dam Safety Program Act.
